results.title: Lottie Lyell
results.creator_credit: Ben Lewin, Pamela Vanneck, Ron Saunders and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Willesee’s Australians”.
This moving drama series on important figures from Australia’s past brings Australian history to life. Lottie Lyell was one of Australia’s most successful actresses. Although she often played the damsel in distress in her early films, Lottie was no helpless heroine in real life. As well as starring in her films, she worked behind the cameras as script writer, art director, costume designer, editor and business manager. She was part of an excellent team with Raymond Longford, Australia’s best known silent film director with whom she had a long and enduring relationship.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ben Lewin, Pamela Vanneck, Ron Saunders and Film Australia

results.title: Taming the red swamp
results.brief_description: Vision only. Film seems to be about the techniques employed to make waterlogged land usable for crops. Footage includes old-style farm vehicles and machinery being used to achieve this. Nice shot of 6 new red tractors driving through the terrain. Also features an amusing moment where two men push a large poll into the ground to prove how soft the soil is. General shots of cattle are scattered throughout. Nice, kitsch begining and end illustrated titles. Good ‘The End’, possibly for postcard.

results.title: Potash deficiency Hamilton district
results.brief_description: No sound. Long-duration shots of clovers, fields and farmers walking through fields. Ends with footage of a manually-operated farming device that either plants seeds or removes plants.

results.title: Tractor driving
results.brief_description: Very clearly this film gives hints on the maintenance, driving and safety precautions to be taken with a tractor. “A well maintained machine will be a safer machine and give you better value over its work life.”

results.title: The Voice of Agriculture
results.creator_credit: Tony Doogood and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short film is an advertisement for the radio broadcast “The Voice of Agriculture”. Typical of the (now outdated) representation of gender roles of the time, the film opens with a domestic scene in which the mother of the family is making dinner while her husband discusses farm work. The farmer, who is having trouble with his sheep, calls on professional help from a veterinarian at the Department of Agriculture, who informs him about the radio program “The Voice of Agriculture”, which is designed to help farmers like him. The film then shows the behind-the-scenes production of the broadcast, including voice actors, radio technicians and vintage wireless sets.

results.title: Green Fingers: Pest and Disease Control
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this is an archival film and contemporary advice should be sought when handling chemicals and poisons.

‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Pest and Disease Control’, Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to use agricultural sprays on a rose garden at Burnley Gardens.

Diseases described include black spot, aphids and powdery mildew. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Mice Milking
results.brief_description:
Please be advised: this film contains scenes of animal restraint that some viewers may find disturbing.

This film, made by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, documents the process by which mice are milked in a laboratory at the Safe Research Farm in Werribee, for use in cancer research. The narrator explains that in mice, leukemia and mammary cancer are similar to cancer in humans and the virus is present in their milk. The mice milking machine in use in the film was developed by research officer Graeme Mein for demonstration in an open day at Werribee, based on those used by the National Cancer Institute, USA. The film shows laboratory technicians attaching a mouse to the machine and milking them.

results.title: Green Fingers: Planting Evergreens
results.brief_description: ‘Green Fingers’ was a series of short instructional films on home gardening tips, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture. In this episode, ‘Planting Evergreens’, gardener Rod Cantrill demonstrates how to correctly plant evergreen trees and shrubs in your garden, accompanied by a narrator explaining the method and techniques. The episodes of ‘Green Fingers’ are an early example of popular gardening shows in the tradition of ‘Sow What’, ‘Better Homes and Gardens’, and ‘Gardening Australia’.

results.title: Dressing a Chicken
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description:
Please be advised, this film features footage of dead animals.

Produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, this short instructional film demonstrates the correct method for cleaning and dressing poultry. The film is an interesting historical insight into the changing nature of food production and distribution. It would once have been normal for people to handle a fresh chicken carcass rather than a pre-prepared one from the butcher, and the size of the chicken is considerably smaller than today’s standards.

production_dates.notes: based on film edge code manufacture dates

results.title: 1957 Pig Carcase Competition
results.brief_description: Details and promotes the 1957 Pig Carcase competition as well as pork production in Victoria as a whole. Similar to the 1955 Pig Carcase competition in format and style. Includes various shots of carcases being cut for display, general crowd shots, an awards ceremony and a speech by an official. Features fantastic footage of three carcases hanging up in front of a black backdrop being inspected and caressed by a man. Nice theatrical quality to it. Excellent shot of a boy inspecting pork shot from behind, highlighting very cute jeans. End of piece features an official from the Board of Meat, aided by illustrations, talking about how pork production in Victoria has improved over time. Behind him hang carcases and behind them there is a red wall. He wears a pink and red tie. This creates a quirky, very good-looking frame of man, meat and pig illustration. Soundtrack features music of the period and earnest narration about ‘pig raisers’.
